{
  "article_text": [
    "most numerical codes used to solve the einstein equations in order to obtain stationary or dynamical spacetimes generated by compact astrophysical objects are based on the 3 + 1 formalism ( see , e.g. , @xcite ) .",
    "the fully constrained formalism ( fcf ) , recently proposed in @xcite , is a constrained evolution formulation of the full einstein equations .",
    "it is a natural generalization of the conformally flat condition ( cfc ) @xcite , which is an approximation of the einstein equations .",
    "fcf extends the cfc approximation and includes a hyperbolic system governing the gravitational radiation .",
    "reader interested in details and motivation about fcf can address to the reference @xcite .",
    "we present numerical simulations of this system in several cases .",
    "given an asymptotically flat spacetime @xmath0 we consider a @xmath1 splitting by spacelike hypersurfaces @xmath2 , with @xmath3 being the timelike unit normal to @xmath2 .",
    "latin ( greek ) indices go from 1 ( 0 ) to 3 .",
    "@xmath4 denotes the 3-metric on @xmath2 and @xmath5 the extrinsic curvature . with the lapse function @xmath6 and the shift vector @xmath7 , the metric @xmath8",
    "is expressed in coordinates @xmath9 as @xmath10 as in  @xcite , we introduce a flat metric @xmath11 , which satisfies @xmath12 and @xmath13 at spatial infinity .",
    "we define @xmath14 and @xmath15 .",
    "we introduce the following conformal decomposition : @xmath16 .",
    "we define @xmath17 .",
    "the gauge in  @xcite is _",
    "maximal slicing _",
    ", @xmath18 , and the so - called _ generalized dirac gauge _ , @xmath19 , where @xmath20 is the levi  civita connection associated with @xmath11 .",
    "the einstein equations become a coupled elliptic - hyperbolic system : the elliptic sector acts on the variables @xmath21 , @xmath6 , and @xmath7 , and the hyperbolic sector acts on @xmath22  @xcite .",
    "if @xmath23 is imposed , cfc is recovered .",
    "we introduce the conformal decomposition @xmath24 , where @xmath25 .",
    "this decomposition is different from the one introduced in  @xcite , but it is motivated by the local uniqueness properties of the elliptic equations shown in  @xcite .",
    "we rewrite the equation for @xmath22 as a first order evolution system for the tensors @xmath26 , where @xmath27 @xcite .",
    "we evolve numerically the previous evolution system for @xmath26 . during the numerical simulations , we consider @xmath6 , @xmath7 , @xmath21 and the energy - momentum tensor as sources of the system .",
    "we perform the evolution of matter with the coconut code @xcite .",
    "some basic elements of this code are : i ) fourth order finite differences scheme for the spatial derivatives and fourth order runge - kutta methods for the time derivative ; ii ) axisymmetry and symmetry with respect to the equatorial plane ; iii ) spherical orthonormal coordinates , @xmath28 ; iv ) a sommerfeld condition at the outer boundary ; and v ) kreiss - oliger dissipative term in order to avoid the numerical noise of high frequency which appears during long - term simulations .",
    "the first test is the evolution of a combination of ingoing and outgoing even - parity axisymmetric teukolsky waves  @xcite , in order to construct regular initial data at the center @xmath29 .",
    "the amplitude chosen is @xmath30 .",
    "these data are a solution of the linearized wave equation in a vacuum , they satisfy the dirac gauge and are traceless ( which is the linear approximation of unit determinant ) .",
    "the background is flat , i.e. , @xmath31 , and @xmath32 .",
    "we display in fig .",
    "[ fig : teu_wave ] the radial profile of the component @xmath33 at @xmath34 , at the equator and at the pole , with different values of the number of radial and angular points respectively",
    ". the analytical solution is recovered in the linear regime , as well as the velocity and the amplitude of the wave , and its decay with the radius .",
    "the absolute errors ( l2 norm ) in the numerical simulations are smaller than @xmath35 for all the non zero components .",
    "the sommerfeld condition at the outer boundary produces ingoing reflections that do not grow in time and have an amplitude much smaller than the amplitude of the initial one .",
    "we obtain second order of convergence for all the non zero components of the tensor @xmath22 , due to the influence of the inner boundary conditions imposed at @xmath36 , @xmath37 and @xmath38 .     at @xmath34 .",
    "right figure corresponds to the equator and left figure corresponds to the pole .",
    "continuous lines corresponds to @xmath39 and @xmath40 ( radial and angular number of grid points ) , @xmath41 and @xmath42 , and @xmath43 and @xmath44 , in non - linear evolutions .",
    "dashed line corresponds to @xmath41 and @xmath42 , in a linear evolution.,title=\"fig:\",width=264,height=181 ]   at @xmath34 .",
    "right figure corresponds to the equator and left figure corresponds to the pole .",
    "continuous lines corresponds to @xmath39 and @xmath40 ( radial and angular number of grid points ) , @xmath41 and @xmath42 , and @xmath43 and @xmath44 , in non - linear evolutions .",
    "dashed line corresponds to @xmath41 and @xmath42 , in a linear evolution.,title=\"fig:\",width=264,height=181 ]      we consider an axisymmetric and uniformly rotating neutron star in equilibrium .",
    "the initial data have been obtained from lorene @xcite , a library of spectral methods .",
    "these models , of different rotation parameters , have non - vanishing @xmath7 , @xmath6 , @xmath21 and matter fields .",
    "all these variables are kept fixed during the evolution of the tensor @xmath22 .",
    "the initial model is a neutron star with a 550 hz rotation frequency , a @xmath45 baryon mass and a 12.86 km coordinate equatorial radius .",
    "figure  [ fig : grid ] shows a sketch of the grid , where the following domains have been defined : the matter domain ( md ) contains the star .",
    "the propagation domain ( pd ) is the one where the waves are well - resolved .",
    "the region for extracting the gravitational radiation is placed at the outer boundary of the pd . the damping domain ( dd )",
    "has a lower resolution in the radial direction .",
    "the wave travels far enough for imposing the sommerfeld condition at the outer boundary before reaching it .",
    "let @xmath46 be the radius which separates the md and the pd , and @xmath47 be the radius which separates the pd and the dd .",
    "the star radius , @xmath48 , is close to th radius @xmath46 but still smaller in value .",
    "the logarithmic scale ( in the radial direction ) is a very useful tool for constructing this kind of grid with a reasonable number of points .",
    "we get the necessary accuracy in the md and the pd , but the time stepping becomes more severe than the one required in an equally spaced radial grid .    as initial data we have used stationary values for the tensor @xmath22 and some differences from stationarity for @xmath49 .",
    "the aim at introducing these initial differences from stationarity is two - fold : on the one hand , the recovering of stationarity from a perturbed initial data , and , on the other hand , testing the outer boundary sommerfeld condition imposed by the generation of the artificial wave . in this general background ,",
    "those differences from stationarity introduced in the initial data , generate a perturbation that propagates to the outer boundary , leaving behind the stationary solution . in fig .",
    "[ fig : stationarity ] , we have plotted the absolute value of the component @xmath33 in terms of the radius for different times .",
    "we can see the perturbation traveling towards the outer boundary , where the wave leaves the numerical domain .",
    "the differences from stationarity are interpreted as an initial perturbation .",
    "the reflections close to the outer boundary come from the numerical implementation of the sommerfeld condition .",
    "second order of convergence is obtained for all the non zero components of the tensor @xmath22 , as previously .    .",
    "dashed line corresponds to the stationary solution ( as reference ) .",
    "continuous lines correspond to the evolution of the initial data at 0.02 , 0.05 , 0.1 , 1.0 and 3.0 ms respectively .",
    "vertical lines denote radius between domains.,width=302,height=207 ]     at time @xmath50 ms .",
    "the dashed line corresponds to the stationary solution ( as reference ) .",
    "continuous lines correspond to the numerical evolutions whose outer boundary are placed at @xmath51 , @xmath52 and @xmath53 cm .",
    "vertical lines denote radii between domains.,width=302,height=207 ]    this test helps to understand how the sommerfeld condition at the outer boundary works .",
    "this condition is imposed to treat the outgoing waves which reach the outer boundary , as the one caused by the initial data .",
    "if the background is not flat enough , the sommerfeld condition can interpret the background as an outgoing wave .",
    "this behavior can be seen in fig .",
    "[ fig : out_bound ] for the simulation whose outer boundary is placed closer , at @xmath51 .",
    "the sommerfeld condition works properly for @xmath54 cm ( around 300 stellar radii ) . in our calculations",
    "we have used 80 radial grid points in the md , 80 points in the pd and around 50 in the dd .    .",
    "the dashed line corresponds to the stationary solution ( as reference ) .",
    "continuous lines correspond to the evolution of the initial data at 0.1 , 1.0 and 3.0 ms .",
    "vertical lines denote radii between domains.,width=302,height=196 ]    once the outer boundary radius has been fixed , we can use the stationary initial data for both @xmath22 and @xmath49 tensors . in fig .",
    "[ fig : sta_ini_data ] we show the absolute value of the component @xmath33 , in terms of the radius , for different times .",
    "no initial artificial wave is introduced .",
    "the noise comes from the outer boundary condition .",
    "again , second order of convergence is obtained .",
    "we consider a perturbed neutron star .",
    "the perturbation is proportional to @xmath55 .",
    "since the star is rotating , @xmath48 depends on @xmath56 , and the perturbation is not spherically symmetric ; hence , gravitational radiation is expected to be generated .",
    "the hydrodynamic equations governing the matter evolution are solved .",
    "we keep fixed @xmath6 , @xmath7 and @xmath21 , assuming that they do not change very much during the evolution .",
    "this test will provide where to place @xmath47 , and , consequently , where to extract the gravitational radiation .    in fig .",
    "[ fig : wave_e ] , an approximation of the real part of the weyl scalar @xmath57 , @xmath58 , ( scaled with @xmath59 ) is plotted in terms of the retarded time , for different values of the extraction radius , at the equator . this approximation is accurate enough for the objectives of this test .",
    "@xmath47 is placed at @xmath51 cm ( around 30 stellar radii ) .",
    "the waves correspond to the physical gravitational waves coming from the evolution of the perturbed star .",
    "this evolution is governed by the coupled hydrodynamic and the einstein equations ( but keeping fixed @xmath6 , @xmath7 and @xmath21 ) .",
    "the different curves in fig .",
    "[ fig : wave_e ] refer to different radii where the gravitational radiation has been extracted . from this figure",
    ", we can deduce that the speed of the waves is the light velocity and they decay as @xmath60 .",
    "we also see that the wave must be extracted far from the source but inside the pd . regarding the resolution of the logarithmic grid",
    ", we have noticed that it is enough to cover a wavelength with five points at the end of the pd in order to obtain the wave accurately .     versus the retarded time .",
    "the corresponding wave is extracted at @xmath61 , @xmath62 and @xmath63 cm , at the equator .",
    "@xmath47 is placed at @xmath51cm.,width=302,height=181 ]    furthermore , it will be important to know where to place @xmath47 . in fig .",
    "[ fig : extrac_r ] , @xmath64 is plotted in terms of the retarded time in simulations with different @xmath47 .",
    "the wave is extracted close to @xmath47 in all the cases . from the figure ,",
    "it is reasonable to place @xmath47 at @xmath51 cm ( around 30 stellar radii ) or further .     versus the retarded time , at the equator .",
    "radii are expressed in cm .",
    "the corresponding wave is extracted at @xmath61 ( @xmath65 ) , @xmath62 ( @xmath66 ) and @xmath67 ( @xmath68).,width=302,height=181 ]",
    "the first version of coconut s code @xcite was designed to evolve matter fields of a perfect fluid in the dynamical spacetime of the cfc approximation .",
    "the current version of coconut incorporates magnetic fields , i.e. , it is a general - relativistic magneto - hydrodynamic code which evolves matter in the dynamical spacetime of cfc .",
    "the present contribution to this conference , together with previous works in @xcite , is a step towards the upgrading of the metric evolution of coconut s code by substituting the cfc approximation of the einstein equations by the fcf of @xcite .",
    "the hyperbolic sector to evolve @xmath22 has already been included into coconut s code . in this contribution",
    "we have shown that this sector works properly .",
    "we have presented the numerical evolution of teukolsky waves in a flat background .",
    "we have analyzed the behavior of the code under the sommerfeld boundary condition , and detected the outer radius , in the case of spacetimes generated by equilibrium configurations of rotating neutron stars . finally , we have extracted the gravitational waveforms in the case of dynamical spacetimes generated by perturbed rotating neutron stars .",
    "i. c .- c . acknowledges support from the spanish ministerio de educacin y ciencia ( ap2005 - 2857 ) . this work has been supported by the ministerio de educacin y ciencia through grant no .",
    "aya2007 - 67626-c03 - 01 and by the collaborative research center on gravitational wave astronomy of the deutsche forschungsgemeinschaft ( dfg sfb / transregio 7 ) ."
  ],
  "abstract_text": [
    "<S> this contribution summarizes the recent work carried out to analyze the behavior of the hyperbolic sector of the fully constrained formulation ( fcf ) derived in bonazzola et al . </S>",
    "<S> 2004 . </S>",
    "<S> the numerical experiments presented here allows one to be confident in the performances of the upgraded version of coconut s code by replacing the conformally flat condition ( cfc ) approximation of the einstein equations by the fcf . </S>"
  ]
}
